narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Marissa Weiss  Marissa was very helpful and accessible. She was both very organized and helped facilitate the class smoothly, as well as very knowledgeable about the topic and easily approachable.
Instructor: Marissa Weiss  Marissa Weiss
Instructor: Marissa Weiss  Marissa Weiss
Instructor: Marissa Weiss  Weiss, Marissa

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Marissa Weiss  Marissa was well organized and always open to suggestions and willing to help at any point in the semester.
Instructor: Marissa Weiss  Marissa was a wonderful TF. She was always available to answer questions throughout the semester and during our final paper. She was well-organized and a great resource.

Instructor: Marissa Weiss  Marissa was always available to students and performed the duties requested by the professor. I sense that she could have had a much more active role this semester, but was not empowered to do so by the professor.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I'm really glad that I took this course because it gave me a good taste of what land-use planning is all about. At the same time, I wish that I could've delved deeper into some of the topics we were discussing. I actually ended up going back and looking at some of the online lectures just to clarify my understanding of the laws and policies and I found that particularly helpful for review and consolidating my thoughts and ideas. Because of the short length of the class sessions, and relying primarily on lecture, there isn't really a whole lot of time to dive into the complexity behind the topics we discuss. I think the readings to help to give more depth, and improve questions and discussions during class. I kind of wish we'd had a bit more time though each week. Maybe make it 1.5 credits, add in one more response paper and meet a bit longer? Just some thoughts.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I enjoyed the content and the overview of land use planning from a mostly urban/suburban/built environment perspective.
I really liked the case study with Derby! I thought the opportunity to do a facilitation was really very eye-opening and wish that more opportunities like this could exist in the future.

This class provides a really great introduction into the planning and land use world. Jessica Bacher teaches the course in a very clear and straightforward manner. It covers a wide variety of planning topics in a short amount of time, but does so in a way that doesn't feel overwhelming or shallow. The field trip to Derby was also a great way to experience elements of the planning process first hand.
-Field trip to Derby -Guest speakers
Very helpful as a survey of the field and launching off point for students seeking to later deepen knowledge of an aspect of land use. Would recommend especially to first year students.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: It would be better if there was more of a discussion component to the course. The lectures often ran long because there was a lot of material, but it would have been more helpful if the lectures were either 90 minutes (instead of 60) so that we were not rushed and we could apply the concepts we were learning to more real-world scenarios.

I be great if there could be a bit less summary and instead more depth to each of the issues we examine. I liked the use of different examples of implementation in cities and towns used throughout the course. Again, wish we had more time to discuss more of the challenges.
The class always ran late. While we were always interested in the topics and happy to stay longer, the timing of the lectures could be improved so they don't feel too rushed at the end.

-There was minimal discussion/interaction in this class. Instead of just moving through a powerpoint each session, I suggest incorporating small group assignments/reports, more guest speakers, and creating more opportunities for student participation.

I think the class might work a little more smoothly if a little less material was packed into each slide show presentation--with the disclaimer that the rest of the slide show material would be available online. Or perhaps getting 1.5 hours per week instead of 50 min? This latter solution would probably be better as the instructor had a lot of good material to cover, but was often rushed to get through it each week.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am very interested in the intersection of urban land use planning and innovative and alternative energy systems. For methis class was useful because it gave me a sense as to what are the requirements and the processes that one must use to use land or change its use.

I'm really glad I took this course because give me a critical background in land-use planning, but also expose me to an entirely different track at FES that's definitely worth exploring in my time at the school.
I'm hoping to focus my studies on land use planning and development, so this course provided a nice introduction into the topics.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It is something I thought I was interested in, and it was nice to have a one credit course with little work that gave me the opportunity to explore this interest.

I took this course because I wanted some exposure to the process of land-use planning. I wanted to learn more about the planning field and how it works and see if the topic is worth pursuing during the remainder of my time at FES.
I took this course to get a general sense/overview of the land use planning field.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Mostly, it would have been nice to talk more about urban areas more specifically, but since it was a survey course (as advertised), there were too many topics to cover to go into specifics
Yes, I feel like for one credit class this was just what I needed. Though I wish again there had been some more depth in certain topics.
Yes - for a one credit class, this was very informative and helpful.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: This class is an easy, one-credit course. It gives you a general understanding about the process of land planning in urban and suburban areas, integrating community involvement and policy. This course does not talk about more rural areas or wilderness, but it is a good start into the planning world.

It is a really great introductory class that I highly recommend. The work commitment is relatively small though you do need to attend most of the classes. The land-use program is a really great part of FES and more people should be exposed to it. Jessica is a really knowledgeable and willing to answer all questions people have. I particularly like how well networked the land-use collaborative and the course are with the region in Connecticut. This is one of the few opportunities I had to really explore local areas during my time at FES, and I've been inspired to take more planning classes in my time here.

If you have a planning background of any kind, you do not need to take this course. It is definitely just an introduction to the field and not meant to do a deep dive into any particular subject. However, if you are curious about what planning is, this is a great place to start and a very engaging class. I always looked forward to attending this class.

Highly recommend as a launching off point for students interested in learning more about land use. This course builds a helpful framework and context of the field that will support further studies. Most helpful as a course for first year students or students with little background in the field. Also, great opportunity to get to know instructor Bacher who is great, very responsive to students, and does a lot of interesting work through the land use clinic.
